description: A borrowing of French tellurique, from Latin tellus (“earth; earthy”) and Tellus (“Earth, Gaia”) and -ique (forming adjectives). Subsequently also from tellurium, originally in telluric oxide from German Telluroxyd.

adjectives.description: telluric (comparative more telluric, superlative most telluric)

entries.meaning: (chemistry) Containing tellurium in a lower valency than in tellurous compounds.

examples: Other projects in progress at CRPL involve the study of audiofrequency tellurics (current induced in the earth) and earth conductivity measurements using atmospherics.
